review: the quality of the picture when using this device is not good.  It is bad enough that I resorted back to hard wiring my TV to the computer with the HDMI cable.  Also I have to keep my computer on while casting to TV and the delay time is so obvious that it is completely distracting. Also doesn't work with my IPAD (I have the old version of IPAD).  Unfortunately it was a waste of money for me, but a slick idea.  maybe once they perfect it?
author: lzj

review: There was a lot of hype for the Chrome and for $35 we decided to try it.  Its cheaper than a roku or other device, but really has limited use at this point.  So far there are just a few services that you can use to project onto your TV:  (1)  Netflix streaming, which has very limited programs (2) Pandora, which can be steamed to a tablet or other device (as you don't watch it); (3) hulu (we don't have this) and (4)  google play (where you need to buy the movies). You can also show your chrome browser on your TV, BUT, this can only be done from a laptop, not a tablet.  I tried to watch movies in Amazon Prime through the chrome browser using Chromcast, but it always kicks out errors.  If there was an Amazon Prime app for Chromecast, It would be amazing-- but without that it really just provides another way to view the internet or a means to watch very limited program or use apps that aren't great.
